I was sure "Middle school grades" was going to be CEES.  Too clever.

Excellent puzzle. I had to consult the I Ching a couple times to divine the answers. Once I got the Soap-on-a-rope Box thing, the rest fell in place.

I got to thinking about People's "Sexiest Man Alive". It seems so limiting. I, for one, would be far more interested in the 368,427,301st Sexiest Woman Dead. I just think I could relate to the whole thing a lot better.

Clever clues: Bud of Nancy; J, F or K; and Middle-school marks. Great stuff.

Exactly! We have the basic mental ingredients of the likes of Representatives Burgess of Texas (masturbating fetuses), Todd Akin (the female body shutting that whole thing down), Gohmert (anything he says), Texas and North Carolina GOP-controlled statehouses just to name a few.

I don't think so, babe.  You forgot that we are involved in an active war.  How could you forget that?  There are accidents (I think perhaps in some ways car travel hazards are increasing),  but this is different.  You think we have sacrificed to combat terrorism??? That sounds like a joke to me.  We are very comfortable in our safe lives right now, and leave the dangers to the military and other federal contractors and employees and local police forces.  That's not a sacrifice! We have a problem with gun control, conservatives, tea partiers, constitutional justification lunatics, but hey that's America, isn't it? Always has been these problems.  Combating terrorism is a whole different cake.  Sometimes I wonder if you're losing touch with reality, when you seem so grounded in the reality of the whole world...!  Guess I'll keep wondering!

I'm afraid I have basically lost hope that the government(s) of this can ever be a rational deliberative bodies. While the majority of the electorate seems to be so there is a fairly large minority of very loud, well organized fools who hold most elected officials in terror of their wrath (electoral might). Their rise to power is basically due to the explosion in communication systems that allow them to seem so much larger that their numbers would warrant.

H.L. Mencken (I think) said that.... "Democracy is the theory that the common man knows what is best and deserves to get it good and hard."

welcome back! as usual; great to read your thoughts/commentary once again.. .admittedly our priorities may be skewed and more of our resources could/should go toward the prevention  of violence ( education,schools,alleviation of poverty etc)..but I disagree more   gun laws per se will stop violence gun violence..i.e .South Africa has some of the most strict  gun laws but yet has some of the highest crime rates using guns on the planet.

Welcome back!  You've been missed.  In answer to the question, "How Could We Blow This One?"  Very easy, we have elected a Congress full of gutless wonders beholden to special interests.  It's really sad.

Great column,agree with you but I also think the press has failed to do their part to keep our congress on track. The press,written and media, keep flying from topic to topic . Snowden is big because of the media not because of US citizens. Gun culture got lost because the voice of the pele,media/press,walked away instead of holding our reps. Accountable.. We have to stay on our congress. They are one of our largest concerns/failures. The people can also do their part but solving issues,jobs,guns,immigration can only be accomplished with  a "voice" for the people .your column is a good start. Identify and reporting facts rather than printing political tripe will help the 91% get a problem solved.

I haven't been reading the NYT or listening to the media much lately because the press seems to have forsaken its duty and joined the entertainment industry.  Your refreshing honesty and fairness today about 2 pressing problems for Americans is greatly appreciated, Mr. Kristof.  I believe that President Obama would agree with you 100% and welcome a decent and intelligent discussion about: 1. How do we best prevent domestic gun deaths? and 2. Is it possible for Americans/others to maintain their privacy and realistically be protected from attacks by terrorists?  Unfortunately, it seems that only bashing and trashing of the president seems to sell advertisements.  Most of us out here in the real world want to hear more about the good that is being accomplished in America and the world, including the good that President Obama has accomplished during extremely difficult times.  We are tired of the mean-spiritedness and nastiness of Ted Cruz, Mitch McConnell, et al.

Your columns are always informative and thought provoking.

I believe that one of the important factors in passing some reasonable gun-control laws is that the gun enthusiasts are probably correct about one of their major assumptions: That assumption being that many people will not just stop with these kinds of restrictions, but are in fact wanting to eliminate guns completely. A "creeping liberalism" kind of idea.

Many gun owners may not really fighting back against this specific type of legislation, but are worried that if they don't hold the line here, they will be defending another, more restrictive, line somewhere else.

I don't believe this is an unfounded worry. And it is a barrier to reasonable gun control legislation.

Do people who are advocating for this type of legislation make it clear in all of their public pronouncements and in their actions that if this legislation is passed that this is it: That this is as far as it will go?

I think not. So those of us who are in favor of reasonable gun laws should perhaps point the finger at ourselves for the lack of progress, and not at those who fear losing their right to own and use guns.

I am so glad you are back! I have missed your column so much. This column depresses me. I see the money in politics subverting the will of the people (reasonable background checks). The Snowden affair coverage has mostly been concerned with his situation instead of the information we have learned from him. Too bad- the media could do so much more.
Mr. Kristoff is  Right On in every respect!

Thank you for reminding me of the precious value of freedom on this Independence Day. (I had to smile at your piece in the Post, as I understand only too well your frustration with bad manners, even if the contexts are not even close.) May God bless you and yours.

You conflate inalienable rights with legal rights. The Declaration of Independence concerns inalienable ("unalienable," to use its language); the Constitution concerns legal rights. Legal rights exist at the consent of the governed -- they can be amended or changed by the democratic process. The 2nd Amendment, however one interprets it, is no exception.

I hope this helps you understand why so many people do not agree with you, your colleagues colleagues at Fox News, and your fellow conservatives in Hunterdon County, executive washrooms, and the Republican Party.

Well Mr. Kristof, all you have to do is to look at the comments on your column to see why the post-Newtown gun legislation failed.  The rhetoric and thinking are polarized and ossified.  It's a stalemate.  To change the situation, you'll have to bring something different to the party.  Good luck.

James Madison’s first draft of the 2nd Amendment:
"The right of the people to keep and bear arms shall not be infringed; a well armed, and well regulated militia being the best security of a free country: but no person religiously scrupulous of bearing arms, shall be compelled to render military service in person."

Note the final clause, relating to conscientious objectors. A CO exemption only makes sense if the amendment refers to a military force.

There was a mass shooting in Texas around the same time as the one in Oz. We here responded by allowing, for the first time, licensed responsible adults to carry concealed handguns as a deterrent. And there has not been a mass shooting here since then either. (except by an Army Psychiatrist at Ft. Hood). The population size and urban/rural split are quite similar.Gun crime has decreased over the last 20 years.in both places, rather more in Texas..
Is there a cause and effect relationship? It is hard to tell.
However, gun-control advocates loudly claimed at the time concealed carry laws were established that gun violence would certainly increase. That alone is a big reason why gun control is so suspect in these parts.
FWIW, the Bill of Rights in its actual form was mostly the brainchild of the fervently anti-slavery Samuel Adams of Boston. His second listed Right stated, more or less, "law abiding citizen may keep their arms."

Please cite a source for the "90%." I realize that the kind of violence you name is all too real, but I also read about many, many other types of gun death.

Male between 20 and 50 gets left by a girlfriend/wife, buys a gun, kills woman, often himself, sometimes the children. Innocent bystanders are shot by someone with bad aim or in a panic. Kids play with the gun they've discovered at home. Suicide by people (statistically, in comparison to other countries) would change their mind if the method weren't so quick and easy.

That's 2,000 of the 30,000 annually? 7%? Jonathan at 10:26 a.m. says the percentage is 90%?

What do you propose in order to reduce the 28,000 gun deaths that represent the 93%? In Australia, Canada, Europe, the citizens don't have such a gun problem.

Gun owners would have no issue with "Universal Background Checks" if assured that such a system would not be used to facilitate universal confiscation. Regardless of how such a law were written, this government and future governments would break such assurances on a whim and it is useless to deny it. Look up what happened in New Orleans post Katrina.
The notion seems reasonable on the surface but is very unlikely to reduce gun crime because gun criminals will ignore it. So, what is the real goal?
Devices that limit who can operate a gun also seem reasonable, at first. The problem is, there is such a thing as legitimate self defense. And when that is taking place, when fear of impending death or great bodily harm is all too real, the would be victims body is most likely in a severely altered state from floods of adrenaline. Motor skills are impaired. There is no technology on the horizon that would reliably work in those conditions. Requiring the use of faulty devices would just be a round-about way of out-lawing lawful self defense.

I went to your link and after a picture popped up waited for the "controversial" image that would provoke such violence. After 10 seconds realized it was the picture I was staring at and it made me realize how far we have to go to bridge the divide on the second amendment. Makes me sad. I still struggle with understanding why we can't have more open discussion and debate. We need to move forward and work together for a safer country.

My gun-sense blog, "End the Madness Now" (www.endthemadnessnow.org) is riding into the sunset with regret but with pride in trying to keep the issue of gun safety afloat in the conscience of the nation.

Sandy Hook momentarily focused our country's attention because such atrocity isn't supposed to happen to innocent six-year-olds in peaceful suburban neighborhoods.

Man-made child-slaying driven by greedy madness wrapped in a flag of the 2nd Amendment, indeed, shouldn't happen ANYWHERE! But it's happening EVERYWHERE in America, nearly 6000 slayings since Newtown. We're simply not hearing about it.

A dear friend recently sported a mild bumper sticker urging sensible, regulated gun safety. Here's the link to said sticker : http://endthemadnessnow.files.wordpress.com/2013/01/cropped-etmnow-heade...

Confrontational, huh? Under the cover of night, someone brave in America heaved a rock through her rear car window. Maybe this was a random act of violent vandalism totally unrelated to my friend's exercise of her 1st Amendment right, but no nearby car windows were smashed that night.

Nobody was physically hurt, but the violation of unprovoked assault stings. Until now, "ETM Now" has distributed free bumper stickers. Not wishing to put decent Americans at the mercy of "patriots" who mask their "constitutional" outrage with cheap-shot attacks from the shadows, "ETM Now" is taking a time-out.

Alas, this seems the quality of 2nd Amendment "debate."

www.endthemadnessnow.org

Zainab,

I write with deep gratitude for your writing in Nick Kristof's blog, and for your ethical and spiritual presence in the world. I dedicate my July 4th to you, and to peace and well being in our world. Thank you for standing strong socially and sharing an interior life that reflects your vision for a present and future of love. You are loved and supported, and you are in my heart and thoughts.

In solidarity,
Cheryl
I hope you are ready to take on the most narcissistic and nihilistic cult on this cult-ridden planet. I am skeptical that you are up to it.

People who don't react to every political issue with hatred towards their opponents have to go through debate dealing with the mental pathology of the anti-gun crowd.

At one time in this country you could actually have a conversation with someone about issues with the other person opening up withOUT a dissertation on why anyone opposed to their idea is by definition insane or evil.

This is exactly why your socialist nirvana (which is where your ideas will take you, on the way to the gulag) contnues to elude you. No one's opinion was ever changed by insults, fake diagnoses, and outright hatred.

The pro-gun view is most generally held by people who have simply lived long enough to know that life involves dangerous situations where police officers will simply not be present.

Growing up aware of our beginnings as a nation, their next question is, ''Am I as deserving of freedom as the patriots?''

Even Milwaukee's head cop admits this.
What if one had to pass  couple of tests to buy weaponry? I am thinking of one on civility and the other on right and wrong, perhaps from a religious viewpoint.

We are tens of thousands of gun laws past the day when ''just pass some kind of law to make a statement of our Good Intentions'' is going to get by the American voter. We have been ''statemented'' long enough.

The ONLY thing that might have prevented the Newtown crime is governmental directives to ID and treat the mentally ill. Let us know when liberal America is ready to take that one on.

Sadly, our urban geniuses are so illogical and over-reactive that seeing some drama where the least thing went wrong in an institutional setting is enough to make millions throw up their hands at the very thought. No country ever lasted long being run on emotion. Ask Mr. Morsi.

In response to your excellent column, I add a small observation: the administration and our security agencies repeatedly state that terrorists have been stopped using the newer, more sweeping measures of surveillance. But that is a false dilemma.

The real question is, would the terrorists have been stopped while keeping the same limitations imposed on the executive branch after Watergate? I suspect the answer is 100% "yes," or that argument would have been offered, instead of the false dilemma.

Your fan,

Kirk Baker
Pastor, Williamson, New York
